content.question:
<math alttext="Z n solid plus C u with a positive 2 charge aqueous is in equilibrium with Z n with a positive 2 charge aqueous plus C u solid; K sub e q equals 2 times 10 to the 37 power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>Cu</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="2.0em"></mspace></mrow></mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>37</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>

A <math alttext="0.10 mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of solid zinc is added to <math alttext="500.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="1.0 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="C u, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. After the mixture sits overnight, which of the following best describes what will most likely be observed and measured the next morning and why?

choices.label: Almost all of the <math alttext="Z n solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> will still be in the beaker with no visible <math alttext="C u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the initial mixture is already at equilibrium due to the very large <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

About half of the <math alttext="Z n solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> will have disappeared and <math alttext="C u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> will have appeared in the beaker, because the system reaches equilibrium.

About two-thirds of the <math alttext="Z n solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> will have disappeared and <math alttext="C u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> will have appeared in the beaker, because the system reaches equilibrium.

Virtually all of the <math alttext="Z n solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> will have disappeared and <math alttext="C u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> will have appeared in the beaker, because the reaction proceeds almost to completion at equilibrium due to the very large <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: Virtually all of the <math alttext="Z n solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> will have disappeared and <math alttext="C u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> will have appeared in the beaker, because the reaction proceeds almost to completion at equilibrium due to the very large <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 6.D: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using chemical principles or laws, or using mathematical justification.
